Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen so this is 
the second video in my Thai language for traveler

series and today we are gonna go over phrases 
that are useful when you are in a restaurant

in Thailand now if you missed my first video 
make sure you check that out first because we

went over some basics some ground rules when it 
comes to Thai language it will help you actually

in this video so let's get started first thing 
that happens when you walk into a restaurant is

probably this they're probably gonna ask you how 
many people in your party and it's gonna sound

like this gee taan ka or gee taan krab gee is how 
many can is a polite way of referring to people

and ka or krab is our polite suffix and if you 
don't know what I'm talking about check out my

first video we went over all of that now if you 
might also hear them say corn cob and corn is

just a different way of saying people so you 
sit down you look at the menu now you need to

call your server so what do you call them now you 
could just say car towed car which is I'm sorry or

excuse me we learned that in the previous video or 
if you want to sound like a local you can say this

Nong Khai or pika so know it's a term that refers 
to somebody who is younger than you like a sister

or brother and P is somebody who's older than you 
so this does require you to make a judgement on

whether they're older or younger than you which 
might make you nervous but don't be nervous no

one's gonna check your ID like ty people have to 
decide all the time whether we're gonna call them

nhong or p so just say something you call your 
server successfully now you need to tell them

that you need to order your food so how do you 
say can I please order my food you would say sang

a han no attack or for Men song a han nightclub 
sang mean to order a han is food no makes it a

request and cap or cup is our polite suffix so 
Santa had like you've ordered you've had a few

beers and now it's time to go to the bathroom 
so where is the bathroom Honam unite Hong Nam

is bathroom U is is nigh is where so bathroom is 
where cat so how to get your bill now that you're

ready to leave it's actually half English check 
big night huh check is check like the same word

in English bin is a Thai accent for bill because 
we don't actually do l at the end of words so they

all gets turned into an N so Ben Nye as we have 
seen makes it a request kha makes it polite check

be tonight ha or check be tonight crap so it's 
half English super easy but maybe you're not in

a restaurant you're buying something on the street 
and you need to ask how much is this how much is

toe right toe right now if you want to specify how 
much is this one and you're pointing to something

you want to add the word this one which is an 
e so I need how right huh now maybe you're at

a street vendor and you see a mysterious skewer 
of something you want to know if it's chicken or

pork or beef and you want to ask what is this say 
that I'm me Erika or an e or a cup and me is this

one a try is what so this is a useless question if 
you don't understand the answer that they're gonna

give you so that is precisely the subject of our 
next video we're gonna go over some food terms and

that is it for this video make sure you subscribe 
so you don't miss the next video where we talk

about food terms and if you have suggestions on 
other kinds of language culture videos you want
